title: I Like This Video
content:
Though I'm not so fond of the fact that it needs to exist. It turned up on the pouet.net one-liner. It's nice to see these things reaching the mainstream for once.

[url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJTLL1UjvfU]Clickity[/url].

In other news, I had an interesting dream I was in the middle of a city with a couple of other people. Overnight three nukes had been set off around us. We woke at a very early hour to find their smoky remnants. Shortly thereafter a fireworks display was set off, as a plausible explanation for all the smoke, supposedly as part of a sporting event. It actually formed two dreams, in the midst of which I awoke in the darkness thinking, "Man, I hope that's a dream..."

Prior to that there was another dream where I had sleep paralysis and could only move my hands. Raising them in front of me, I found only faint glowing outlines, and announced, "My hands are invisible!"

Through a related YouTube video I discovered [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invisible_hand]this[/url]. A nice little synchronicity.

title: Re: I Like This Video
content:
There isn't much we can do about it, is there?

And of course the rich can pay to get their information deleted and their surveillance disabled. Hurray. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

Yeah, it really annoys me, and just see and watch, our security will not at least improve because of all this stuff.

Just remember to be as ambiguous as possible, that's what I'm going to do. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortlol.gif[/img] 3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: I Like This Video
content:
Hmm...does that fact that I don't care that people know everything about me wrong?--------------------
[url=http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/]Cerebral Cortex 314[/url] - For All of your Commander Keen Needs.
[url=http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/dave/joes.html]Eat at Joes[/url]
It's not wrong, Flaose--but there's a huge difference between your name and your credit card number, etc. Identity theft and fraud online are scary things.

title: Re: ...
content:
Is that anything like the fact that staff at department stores can legally watch you undress?
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Say what now?
content:
Wha? That's well and truly illegal here... though that's the sort of scenario that can come about if the situation isn't kept in check.

I certainly don't mind my activities being monitored in public, since I'm not one to perform suspicious acts. However, you really need to be able to trust that the people that will use the information are benevolent. And I don't.

title: Re: Say what now?
content:
Well I've always figured that if you're out in public, then other people can see what you're doing, so why not cameras too? My only concern is when things you wouldn't do in public are also monitored (e.g. a phone conversation you wouldn't repeat in public, or e-mail/IM.) Thank goodness for encryption.

Interestingly enough their take on trusted computing (that you can only run MS programs, and not say Linux) was odd, considering Linux itself supports trusted computing. They also make it sound like people will be forced to buy computers with 'trusted computing chips', but I'd be surprised if a) no manufacturers offer TPM-free alternatives or b) 'how to desolder your TPM chip' takes longer than a couple of weeks to appear online [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

title: Re: Say what now?
content:
I never do anything suspicious, but whenever I'm around police, or in a store, etc, I feel like they're gonna THINK I'm doing something wrong. (Like when I'm looking at stuff in the store, I'm afraid it'll look like I'm trying to shoplift.) Idk. I get really paranoid over nothing.

What exactly is trusted computing? Is it just a concept, or is it being used now?-Genius314
[url=http://planetck.spatang.com]PlanetCK[/url]

title: Re: Say what now?
content: Wikipedia has a good summary of [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Computing]what trusted computing is[/url].

title: Re: Say what now?
content:
The old saying; 'Who watches the watchers?'

And yeah, here people can watch you undress in changing rooms if ther is no other surveilance avalible.
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!

title: Re: Say what now?
content:
Hah, Genius314, me too.. I always feel like I'm suspicious when I'm trying to decide what candy I'll buy. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-yorp.gif[/img]

I don't think it's legal to watch in changing rooms here, but I don't think they have really bothered to set the cameras so that nothing would show. I better start giving the finger at the ceiling, just in case. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

If one does nothing wrong -- and especially then -- I don't think anyone should know about our movement, things we buy, and such, not anyone we don't want to know. Sure, people can see you down the street walking and doing whatever you do, but people seldom track you 24/7 and remember your every move and coordinates. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] Or every single item you buy within the month.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Say what now?
content:
With RFID tags, it may be posible not only to track and list what you buy, but also to track where those bought items go, and even scan someone to see where they bough the clothes they're wearing, etc.
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v499/Nevad/menbun.gif[/img]

Cute bunny!
